active_learning.discussion_prompt: How would you apply this concept in your work environment?
active_learning.peer_teaching: In pairs, one explains authorization vs. authentication with diagrams (e.g., flowcharts), then switches; teach-back includes drawing an RBAC model and quizzing on misconceptions like assuming all resources need authentication.
active_learning.problem_solving: Groups design authorization requirements for an e-commerce app (e.g., user roles for checkout, admin inventory). Simulate bypass attacks (e.g., privilege escalation), iterate based on OWASP checks, and present defenses.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Software Development Security. Topic: Authorization Requirements (Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Software Development Security > Software Security Effectiveness > 002_Secure 004_Design and Architecture > Security Requirements Engineering > Authorization Requirements). Builds on prior authentication knowledge. Sources: OWASP Authorization Cheat Sheet (deny-by-default, role-based checks per resource/action, separate from business logic, centralized enforcement); NIST SP 800-63-4 (Digital Identity Guidelines); breaches like Capital One, SolarWinds. Incorporate: - Learning Objectives: [insert the learning_objectives array here] - Active Learning: Inspire cards from discussions (authn not always prereq), peer teaching (diagrams/models), problem-solving (e-commerce design). - Scaffolding: Generate cards evenly across 4 layers: [insert scaffolding_layers here]. Output 30 high-quality flashcards in JSON array: [{'type': 'MCQ|Q/A|Cloze', 'layer': 1-4, 'blooms_level': 'Remember|etc.', 'front': '...', 'back': '...'}]. Follow flashcard_schema exactly. Distractors per protocol. Ensure progressive complexity, metacognition (e.g., 'Why might you confuse this?'), real-world ties. No duplicates; cover models (RBAC/ABAC/PBAC), principles, integration.
